misconceptions.name: Implements a completely different problem instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from physics inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required by the question.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that calculates the average acceleration given v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Uses three double variables v0, v1, t instead of reading 5 integers
No loop to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
Output describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion with or reuse of a different exercise about average acceleration, ignoring the current problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the physics-related code and implement the required logic: read 5 integers in a loop, use an if (n % 2 == 0) check to detect even numbers, keep a running sum, and print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, variables, formula, and output text) targets average acceleration and none of the rubric requirements (5 integers, loop, even check, sum) are present.

evidence.note: This code clearly solves an average acceleration problem (v0, v1, t, and (v1 - v0) / t) instead of reading 5 integers, checking for even numbers, and summing them.

misconceptions.name: Completely missed the problem statement
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate acceleration based on initial velocity (v0), final velocity (v1), and time (t), instead of solving the assigned problem of summing even numbers among 5 user-provided integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task was to write an acceleration calculator, or they submitted code from a completely different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requested task was to read and sum even numbers from 5 input integers.
symptoms: Code reads three double values instead of five integers.
Code performs an unrelated calculation (acceleration = (v1-v0)/t).
Code uses a class name 'AccelerationCalculator' and prints a message about acceleration.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major error in parsing the assignment instructions or submitting the wrong file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt and implement the required logic to read 5 integers and calculate the sum of the even ones.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code entirely implements a different program (acceleration calculation) from the one requested (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: Class name reflects the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned even number sum problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have solved a different assignment or misunderstood which problem to complete.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers, then printing the result.
symptoms: Code reads 3 floating-point inputs instead of 5 integers
No loop to process multiple inputs
No even/odd checking logic
Output calculates acceleration, not sum
Variable names (v0, v1, t) don't match the problem domain
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible copy-paste error, submission of wrong file, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. Write a new program that: (1) reads exactly 5 integers, (2) loops through them, (3) checks each with n%2==0, (4) accumulates even numbers into a sum, (5) prints the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is objectively solving a different problem. This is not a minor coding error but a complete mismatch with the assignment requirements.

evidence.note: Entire program solves physics acceleration problem, not the even number sum problem. Reads 3 values, performs physics calculation, outputs acceleration.

misconceptions.name: Implemented acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading five integers and summing only the even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to calculate the average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, check each to see if it is even using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of the even values, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of five integers.
Only three numeric inputs are read, not five.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No modulus operator (%) or conditional logic is used to filter even numbers.
Core computation is (v1 - v0) / t rather than a sum of selected inputs.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of code from a different assignment (average acceleration) without adapting it to the current specification about summing even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remove the acceleration-specific logic and instead use a loop to read five integers, check each with n % 2 == 0, add even values to an accumulator variable, and print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (inputs, variables, formula, and output message) matches an acceleration problem and none of it addresses reading five integers or summing even numbers.

evidence.note: This code reads three values (v0, v1, t), computes (v1 - v0) / t, and prints an acceleration message instead of summing even numbers from five integers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect use of variables for required task
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program for calculating acceleration (using variables v0, v1, t, acceleration which are doubles) instead of the required program for summing even numbers (which requires 5 integer inputs and an accumulator).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or submitted code from a completely different assignment (e.g., an acceleration calculator) instead of the 'Sum of Even Numbers' program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should declare an integer accumulator and use integer variables for input storage, aiming to solve the specified problem.
symptoms: Code solves an entirely different physics problem (acceleration calculation).
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs.
Variables have names v0, v1, and t.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major confusion on which problem to solve or accidental submission of incorrect source code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the program from scratch focusing explicitly on reading five integers and calculating their even sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is clearly calculating acceleration, which has zero overlap with the assigned task of summing even numbers.

evidence.note: Class name reflects physics problem, not the required math problem.
The core logic calculates acceleration, which is irrelevant to finding the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing core logic (modulo and conditional check)
misconceptions.description: The student failed to implement the fundamental logic necessary to identify and filter even numbers (i.e., using the modulo operator and an if-statement). This core requirement is completely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: Since the student submitted the wrong program entirely, they naturally failed to include any logic related to even number detection.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Checking for even numbers requires the expression `number % 2 == 0` usually within a conditional statement.
symptoms: No use of the modulo operator (%) in the code.
No conditional statements (`if`) used for filtering.
misconceptions.root_cause: The code submitted does not correspond to the problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review how the modulo operator (%) is used to determine divisibility and how `if` statements filter data.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The required logic for even number checking is verifiably missing because the code is not about numbers at all, but physics.

evidence.note: The entire functional part of the code lacks any filtering or modulo operation for checking even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing iteration structure (loops)
misconceptions.description: The requirement was to process 5 inputs. The student used sequential input statements for 3 variables instead of a loop (e.g., `for` loop) to handle repeated input reading and processing efficiently.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading inputs one by one manually is sufficient, or they neglected the iterative requirement entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Reading five inputs is most efficiently handled using a loop structure that iterates exactly five times.
symptoms: No loop keywords (`for`, `while`) are present.
Input reading is done sequentially three times, not five.
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of relevant structural elements due to submitting the wrong program.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Implement a `for` loop that runs 5 times to read each input inside the loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No loops are present in the provided source code.

evidence.note: Inputs are read sequentially (3 times) rather than using a loop structure (5 times).
